It took a few seconds for Kieran's head to stop throbbing and for his eyes to focus again, but when they did, he was stunned to see his formerly diminutive body fill what had until then been a pretty ample-sized pool. His back was leaning against the shallow end, and his legs and paws were hanging out of the water near the deep end. he looked down at his crotch and noticed that his swimsuit had ripped to shreds, seemingly disintegrating under the sudden increase in tiger that they had failed to contain. He was completely naked, open for anybody to see. Luckily, he was the only one in the pool hall just then.

Panicking, Kieran racked his brain for what to do. "I cant stay here," he said to himself. "But where can I go?" Jumping out of the water, he crouched to avoid hitting his head on the ceiling that had seemed so high just a moment ago and quickly made a dash for the emergency exit. He was way too large to fit through even the wide double doors, but he squeezed as tight as he could, though he knocked out most of the wall surrounding the door in the process.

Outside, Kieran looked around, hoping no one was there to see him. The school grounds were deserted for the most part, and he hid behind the three-story athletics building fairly well, though it wasn't the hardest thing in the world to make out the towering teen tiger from a distance. As he hurried to a more secluded spot, he thought to himself, "How did this happen to--" He stopped in mid-thought, realizing exactly what had caused this. "Beatrice!" Of course! She had given him that vial of nasty-tasting whatever-it-was to drink, and said it was a bit of 'liquid courage'... It had to be her doing!

Looking around in frustration, Kieran let out a loud growl. "Beatrice!!!"

From around the corner, he heard the mink's distinctive chuckle. "What is it, ti-- Whoa!!!" she gasped in surprise as she rounded the corner and saw all thirty feet of Kieran in front of her.

"What the hell, Beatrice?" Kieran cried out, pointing a finger at her. "I can't believe you did this to me!"

"Calm down, kid," she said, as she walked up to him, coming up only to his shins. "I didn't know it would work that well. Guess I may have made the serum a little too potent."

"So you did do this!" Kieran said. "Change me back, please!"

"I can't," the mink replied. Kieran started freaking out, so she continued. "Don't worry, it'll wear off eventually. But why don't you take advantage of this now, while you have the chance?"

"Are you psycho?" Kieran exclaimed. "I can't have anyone see me like this!!"

Beatrice grinned, and pointed a finger behind Kieran. "I think it may be too late for that. Look."

Kieran turned around and saw that the entire swim team, plus the coach, were al standing outside the pool hall doors, staring up at their massive teammate. Devon was standing in the front and center of the group, mouth open in shock. As Kieran cringed, he prayed that this was all a dream, and that he'd wake up any minute now.

Opening his eyes, he saw that Devon had stepped out in front of the group, coming up closer to his foot. The otter, who before was a good seven or eight inches taller than him, now couldn't even reach his knees. Kieran expected Devon to be frightened, but instead he looked more curious than anything.

"Wow," Devon said, still staring in awe at Kieran. "What happened to you, K?"

Kieran's eyes lit up in surprise. Devon was actually talking to him now, and, if his eyes weren't fooling him, even looked like he was showing more of an interest than before. Kieran tried to keep his excitement in check. "This is all her fault," he said, pointing at Beatrice. "She gave me some kind of growth serum or something, so I would be..." His voice trailed off as he realized that now probably wasn't the best time to reveal his crush to Devon.

"Really?" Devon asked, ignoring the uncompleted sentence. "That's kinda cool. Do you have any more?" he asked, turning to Beatrice.

"Another batch?!" Kieran exclaimed as his eyes lit up. "No way! This is already getting too insane."

"Oh well," Devon said. "I guess you won't be able to do time trials today, will ya?"

"You're probably right," Kieran said as he thought about it. "If the coach'd let me, though, I could swim a lap in about 0.4 seconds. I just have to lie down."

This made Devon laugh, and Kieran smiled meekly. Maybe this whole giant mix-up wasn't such a bad thing after all. It sure seemed to get Devon more interested in him, that's for sure.

"Listen," Devon said, "if you want, we can go for a swim at my house. My family lives in the forest on a lake; it's secluded and the water's deep enough that you'd be able to swim like normal."

Seeing his point, Kieran kneeled down and stuck out his paw, motioning for Devon to climb on. When the otter did, he then lifted him up to shoulder level, where Devon climbed off and grabbed a hold of his fur. The sensation of someone climbing onto him felt strangely pleasant to Kieran, and the fact that it was his secret crush who was wearing only a speedo made it even moreso.

"Hey, wait!" the swim coach called out. "What about your time trials, Devon?"

Devon turned back to face the team. "We'll do 'em tomorrow," he called out, then faced forward again as Kieran started to walk away. "I wasn't really in the mood to do them today anyways," he said in a low voice into Kieran's ear. Kieran grinned out of the corner of his mouth, and they started on the way to the forest where Devon lived.

Kieran's heart beat so fast it nearly jumped out of his chest, and he was glad the lower two-thirds of him was underwater, helping conceal the erection that had suddenly sprung up (or maybe that wouldn't be so bad...). He thinks I'm cute, Kieran thought to himself. The feeling was by all means more than mutual; inside, he wanted to pick Devon up, rip off his shirt and jeans, and go to town, right there in the water, but he knew that wasn't the best of ideas. He just didn't know what was the right way to react; he'd never been in a situation like this before.

As it turned out, however, the choice wasn't up to him. He heard the sound of a car engine revving as it pulled up the driveway, and Devon turned around, his brow furrowed. "Damn," he said, "it's my parents. What are they doing home so early?"

His eyes beginning to fill with panic, Kieran let go of the dock and tried to dive back into the water as much as he could. "What should I do?" he asked Devon, worried.

Devon shook his head, grinning slightly. "Don't fret too much, Shorty. My parents are pretty accepting; I'll just go explain the situation to them, and we'll be as good as gold."

Nodding, Kieran stayed in the water for now as Devon circled around to the front of the house. By the dock it was shallow enough that he could sit on the lakebed and still have most of his head above the water line. He leaned back into the water, so that the only things that were visible were his ears and muzzle.

He thought about what was going to happen with his situation. Sure, Beatrice had said it would wear off eventually, but until then, how was he going to eat, sleep, dress himself or go to school? And of course there was the issue that many people just wouldn't accept a giant in their midst and might start freaking out, calling the cops, the military, or worse. Kieran didn't like thinking of these worst case scenarios, but what other choice did he have? At least one good thing had come of the whole mess. Devon sure seemed much more interested in him than before. It even seemed like he might have been willing to get a little more intimate before his parents showed up. And Kieran liked how Devon had seemed to keep his cool about the whole situation, taking him to his house and still calling him "Shorty", ironic as the nickname was now. At this point, the otter was just what Kieran needed.

After a few minutes, he heard several sets of footsteps approaching, and heard a masculine otter's voice (Kieran guessed that it was Devon's father) saying, "Absolutely not. I don't care what the situation is, you're not having friends stay over on a school night."

"But Dad," Devon said, a slight whine in his voice, "He really needs to."

"Don't argue with your father," a feminine voice, Devon's mother, said. "As long as you live under our roof, you'll follow our rules."

Devon's father continued, "And furthermore-- wait, what the heck is that?"

Afraid he'd been spotted, Kieran dove down completely into the water, trying to avoid being seen. In his haste, though, he had forgotten to take a deep breath, and within a few seconds, his lungs were beginning to burst. He brought his head back above the surface of the water, gasping for air.

"I think they spotted you, Kieran," Devon said with a smirk. "You can stand up now."

Sputtering, and dripping wet, Kieran did as Devon said. His waistline was just about level with the water surface, so he didn't have to worry about covering up in front of Devon's parents. The adult otters both stared at Kieran in wonder, though not as afraid as Kieran had feared.

"So Devon," his father said, "I think you might have had a point about him needing to stay." He turned to Kieran, giving a half-smile that was covering a little bit of apprehension. "So, son, you must be Kieran, right? How on earth did you get so big?"

"Well, sir," the tiger replied, "it's a long story, and I'm not sure of most of the details myself. Let's just say I didn't plan this, that's for sure. And I'm hoping it won't last too long." When he said this, Kieran noticed Devon's ears drooping a little. Was being so much taller than him that much of a turn-on, Kieran thought to himself.

Devon's father nodded, "I see. And Devon says you need to stay here tonight?"

Kieran looked back and forth between Devon and his parents, unsure of how to respond. Sensing his confusion, Devon spoke up. "I told them that it'd be best if you stayed here tonight. I just know that there's not many other places in town where you could go without being spotted and harassed."

Slowly nodding, Kieran replied, "I guess it would make things easier."

"All right then," Devon's father said, "just for tonight. Tomorrow, though, if things haven't gotten back to normal, we'll have to call a doctor... or something."

Kieran nodded, "Thank you very much," he said, bowing slightly out of respect. At least for now, things seemed to be working out all right for him.

The rest of the night went fairly smoothly. Kieran called his parents, letting them know he wouldn't be home tonight and only receiving a slight dose of worried chastising from them. He didn't mention anything about the sudden growth spurt, hoping to not cross that bridge until absolutely necessary. Devon's father offered to have a cookout by the lake for dinner, so Kieran wrapped himself in the towels and sheets that Devon had brought, and gladly chowed down with the family, having three hot dogs and a hamburger. He didn't want to eat any more out of fear of rudeness, but at his size, it was barely enough to keep his stomach from growling through the rest of the night.

As it got dark, Devon tried to find a place in the backyard for Kieran to get comfortable. He had pleaded with his parents to let him sleep outside with Kieran, but his parents wouldn't budge on that. Right before Devon had to go to bed, he made sure Kieran was going to be okay, and gave him a quick hug on the arm, burying his face into Kieran's fur. "Good night, Kieran," Devon said. "See you in the morning."

"Night," Kieran said. "Pleasant dreams."

"Oh, they will be," Devon said, smiling, "as long as you're in them." He winked at Kieran and then slipped in side, leaving the tiger blushing slightly. As he lay down and tried to find a comfortable position on the grass, he thought of how lucky he was to have a friend like Devon. and he fell asleep dreaming of the sexy otter he had always liked, knowing that he liked him in return.

12223111211.content:
Grabbing the flask from Beatrice's outstretched hands, Kieran dashed out of the hallway. "Wait a second," Beatrice called out, hurrying after the overeager tiger outside. By the time she had caught up with him near a dumpster behind the school building, he already had the flask uncorked and was holding it to his lips, the contents disappearing into his mouth.

"Don't go drinking it all at once," Beatrice said, rolling her eyes.

Kieran's lips curled in disgust, and he dropped the flask to the ground, where it shattered. "Yuck!" he said. "That tastes a lot more bitter than before."

"Geez, be careful with those flasks, Kieran," Beatrice said, frowning. "Like I said yesterday, I hadn't written down the ingredients. This was as close as I could get."

The tiger crossed his arms across his chest and started tapping his foot. "Well, why isn't it working yet?" he said, impatiently.

"It's not instant," Beatrice said. "Besides, don't you want to maybe take off your clothes first, so you don't shred them like before?"

"Oh, crap," Kieran said. "They're not even my clothes; I borrowed them from Devon this morning." He started removing his shirt over his head, but as he was unfastening the pants, he started feeling dizzy and his vision blurred. "Ahh, here it comes!" he said. He fell back against the brick wall, trying to keep his balance. His head started to pound as he fell to a seat and blacked out completely.

A few seconds later, he heard the mink's voice calling from somewhere seemingly far away. "Kieran, are you alright? Kieran?!"

The tiger slowly opened his eyes, his vision still fuzzy. He rubbed his head with his paw, trying to ease his headache. "Ughhh," he said, "that didn't feel so good."

"Uh," Beatrice said, her voice definitely a lot more squeaky than before, "well, it seems to have worked. A little too well, I might add."

Opening his eyes, Kieran looked down at where the voice was coming from. Beatrice was standing there, a mixture of awe and worry filling her face. Something seemed a little strange though; the mink was now only half as big as Kieran's foot. "Beatrice," he asked, "what happened? How big am I?"

"I don't know," Beatrice said, shrugging. "Definitely a lot bigger than before. Stand up so we can see."

Kieran slowly came to his feet, leaning against the roof of the school building for balance. He took a double take at what he was leaning on, realizing that the building which he was about the same height as the other day, now only reached his thighs. He stood up to his full height and looked out over the campus, able to see every bit of it with ease.

"Whoa," Kieran said. "Why am I so much taller?"

The mink furrowed her brow, frustrated. "Like I said, I wasn't using exact measurements. Plus, who knows, maybe there's a cumulative effect. It's not like growth serums are an exact science or anything."

Beginning to feel better, Kieran started walking, his clumsy giant feet barely missing Beatrice, almost knocking her several feet into the air. "Hey," she said, "watch it!"

"Oops," Kieran said, snickering. "Sorry 'bout that."

As he continued walking around the campus, Beatrice ran after him, trying to keep up with the seventy-foot tiger's huge strides. "Where are you going?" she called after him?"

"Oh, just looking for someone," Kieran said as he looked down at her, grinning. "I think you know who."

"Sure thing, Shorty," Devon said, rolling his eyes but smiling.

Cars swerved to avoid colliding with the colossal tiger and his feet, and more than one accident was caused by drivers gawking at Kieran as he passed by. A satisfied grin crossed his face; he was starting to get used to being a giant, and even basking in it. He didn't even mind being naked. Having Devon with him and happy made it all the more enjoyable.

It was about a six mile walk to get to downtown, and Kieran covered the distance in a matter of minutes. Devon had to hold on tight as Kieran climbed down from the interstate onto the surface streets. In the office buildings around him, all work was stopped as everyone gasped and stared at the seven-story beast in their midst.

"Don't worry about me," Kieran said, waving his paw. "I'm just here to watch."

"Alright, way to go Kieran!" the otter cheered, taking the ball. He leaned up against Kieran's muzzle, and planted a kiss squarely on his cheek. Kurt thought he saw the little mink wink cheekily. He certainly hoped that Earl was joking. He probably was. I'm just being paranoid Kurt shook his head slightly.

"I mean, you don't mind, do you? I can go back to my house if I'm bothering you," Earl shrugged.

"No! No, don't," Kurt hastily replied. Realizing that he was sounding a bit too eager, he nonchalantly added, "I mean, it doesn't bother me too much, I suppose,"

"Good. I didn't want to drag this crap all the way back,"

The giant raccoon rolled onto his side as Earl slid into his sleeping bag.

"Sorry I didn't have a bag that would fit you," Earl chuckled slightly.

"I'd certainly like to see the sleeping bag that I could fit into," Kurt snorted. "That would be the day..."

"So, ah, I haven't had a sleep-over in awhile now. Are we supposed to play truth-or-dare or something now?"

"If you're at a chick sleep-over, dude. Right now, I'm pretty beat. Let's just catch some Z's for now,"

"You've definitely got a point there. I'm exhausted,"

Earl was asleep almost the same time his head hit the pillow. Kurt watched him silently for awhile.

"Thanks, little guy," he whispered softly.

Earl snored in reply.

Kurt shook his head slightly again. Earl had really gone out of his way to help him again. Why help out an over-sized douche-bag like him? He'd done nothing but make Earl's life miserable for years, and yet the mink came to him in a time of need and kept being kind to him. Kurt couldn't help but smile as he thought about this kindness. Earl really was a great guy. He just hadn't really given any sort of effort to getting to know the mink. Perhaps he should have. But right now, it just felt nice not to be alone.

Kurt noticed Earl shiver slightly in his thin sleeping bag. It was a pretty chilly night, after all. Perhaps he could help a bit. It was the least he could do. Gently lifting Earl into his palm, Kurt rolled back onto his back, setting the little mink down gently in the dense fur on his pectoral. Stretching out, he closed his eyes, drifting off to sleep with a smile on his lips.

****

Sunlight streaming through the trees on the edge of the golf course brought Kurt gently back from sleep. Sitting up, he stretched, patting his chest absent-mindedly. Wait a minute. Where was Earl? Panicked, Kurt searched around his person and surroundings. Had he rolled over in the night and crushed the poor mink?

Heart beating quickly, Kurt looked towards Earl's home. He breathed a sigh of relief as he saw the mink heading towards him. Earl...
12532222111211.title: Company?

choices: ... I have a favor to ask of you,"
... I need to run a couple tests first,"
125322221112111.content:
Kurt rolled back onto his stomach as Earl approached, laboring under a large tray laden with various breakfast foods. No sooner had the mink set the tray down than the giant plucked the entire assortment up between thumb and forefinger. Earl sat down heavily, gaping in disbelief as the entire contents of the tray disappeared down Kurt's throat in a single gulp.

The massive raccoon, for one, almost regretted his meager meal, as his stomach suddenly remembered how hungry it was. Lunch the previous day had been his last meal, and growing to a dozen stories tall hadn't exactly been efficient on the calorie-burning.

“Jeez, don’t worry. I’m not going to eat you or anything. You wouldn’t be much more filling, anyway, Morsel,” Kurt teased, poking at the suddenly anxious mink.

“I guess we’d have to feed you an entire football team to make a dent in that appetite,” Earl laughed nervously.

Kurt lifted Earl off the ground, cupping him in one palm. “I think you’ll find that my appetite hasn’t changed much,” he chuckled. “But I might have to make some edits to the menu if I don’t get some food soon,”

“I’ll try to get some more soon,” Earl promised. “But it’ll be hard to find something for someone of your... stature,”

“Speaking of my stature, have you made any progress in the ‘shrinking me back down’ front? Or am I going to be picking my teeth with lamp posts for the rest of my life?” Kurt shifted into a sitting position.

“Well, I think I might have a couple of ideas,” Earl shrugged. “But I have to do something first,”

“What is that?” Kurt asked.

“Well...”
125322221112111.title: Breakfast and Plans

choices: Kurt sends Earl to bring the pair out.
Kurt opts for a more dramatic entrance.
1253222211121111.content:
Earl toed the ground, trying to look anywhere but the massive raccoon staring at him. “Well, ya see… I’ve got a favor to ask you,” he mumbled eventually.

Propping his chin up on his palm, Kurt smirked down at the nervous mink. “What can the world’s biggest coon do for you?” he asked, poking teasingly at Earl.

“Oh, jeez. I mean, I promise you we’re going to get you normal again as soon as possible. Promise,” Earl hesitated, then grinned a little. “But that doesn’t mean we can’t take advantage of your… stature in the meanwhile,”

"What exactly do you mean by that?" Kurt shifted slightly. "If you want me to go all Godzilla on the town, no chance. I don't want to see how I stack up against the cops,"

"Of course not!" Earl replied. "Though that would be pretty sexy..." he mumbled bashfully.

"No, but really," the mink continued as Kurt blushed deeply. "I'm worried about my... boyfriend, Blake. I haven't heard from him much since he moved away. And what I have heard wasn't good,"

Kurt cut Earl off. "Wait. Blake? As in Blake Caldwell? My old teammate? No fucking way,"

Earl nodded. "Way. We've been dating for awhile. But we had to keep it quiet because his dad wouldn't be able to abide by, well, his son's choice in who he dated, hence the shrinking formula. One of us would get tiny and... yeah. But now that he's gone, apparently his dad is getting worse and worse. But that's where you come in. Maybe one of Blake's old teammates could convince the old douche to ease up, much less one who's bigger than a house,"

The mink's stomach churned as the massive hand of Kurt encircled his torso and lifted him up into the air. "Hey! Would you mind giving me a heads-up before picking me up? It's rough on a little guy like me,"

"Sorry," Kurt mumbled.

"Don't worry. Blake was always the same whenever I was small," Earl replied.

Despite his towering height, it took Kurt several hours to make the journey to the Caldwell residence. He had to cut through the countryside, avoiding roads and other signs of civilization as he doubted his appearance would be appreciated. As the sun began to approach the western horizon, the giant and his companion arrived near the ramshackle ranch Blake and his father called home. A few lights were on in the windows.
1253222211121111.title: A Small Favor

choices: "...back to the school building, where all my stuff is."
"...to the house of a crazy old scientist/inventor friend of mine."
125322221112112.content:
"Hey, little guy," Kurt said softly, secretly glad inside that Earl was okay. Something did look a little different about him, but Kurt couldn't quite place his finger on it yet.

"…Hey" Earl attempted a smile, but Kurt could immediately tell something was troubling him. His small ears drooped slightly, and his nose twitched.

"Okay, what's going on?"

Hesitating, the mink stuck his hands in his pockets, looking down at his feet.

"C'mon, Earl," Kurt was growing impatient. "Tell me."

"Fine," Earl sighed, looking back up at Kurt and putting away any sense of subterfuge. "Well, actually… can't you kinda tell?"

Kurt tilted his head and looked at Earl questioningly. He then glanced down at his body, which seemed just like yesterday: the same muscular build, the same bushy fur, still naked… but something had changed. Was the ground that far away last night? And were the trees only ankle-high yesterday?

"Holy shit! Have I gotten even bigger?"

Earl nodded, almost cowering in fear of retribution. "Yeah. Quite a bit, actually. You're almost two hundred feet tall now."

"WHAT?" Kurt's heart started beating faster, his blood boiling. "What did you do? You were supposed to fix this, not make it worse!"

Earl shrugged. "I didn't do anything! At least last night. I think the formula I gave you yesterday must still be working in your blood stream."

Kurt brought his paw up to his face, closing his eyes and shaking his head. Things certainly were not going the way he'd hoped. He quickly laid back down, his back slamming against the ground in frustration, causing Earl to lose his footing and fall down on his butt. Kurt thought about picking the mink up, squeezing and shaking him until an antidote popped out of his little head. No, he thought, taking deeper breaths and calming himself down, that's not fair. Earl truly is trying to help. Sure, he may have made one mistake yesterday, but he's done more than try to make up for it.

He opened his eyes again and tilted his head back up, seeing the mink's downturned face as he sat on the greens, chin on his paws. He wasn't crying, exactly, but there was certainly a depression setting in. Kurt wasn't one to usually empathize with others, especially nerdy fags, but Earl had become something more-- a friend, Kurt realized.

"Hey, little man," Kurt said, picking the mink up by the shirt collar and gently setting him on his chest, near the same spot where he had placed him to sleep last night, "don't beat yourself up about it."

"But," Earl protested, "I'm the one who screwed up! You're in this whole mess because of my mistake!"

Kurt took another deep breath. "So? We all make mistakes. Do you think I'm always perfect out on the field?" He laughed, shaking his head. "I'd like to think so, but Coach Westin could probably point out things I do wrong every single play. Besides, I wouldn't have even come in contact with your formula if I hadn't been so willing to accept Coach's stupid energy boost salve. In a way, this is kinda his fault… and I guess a little mine."

Earl smiled weakly, his shoulders still sagging. "I guess… but what if I can't get you back to normal size?"

"Hey, you're a complete nerd with all this biology and chemistry crap. I know you'll be able to figure it out. And besides," a playful grin formed across Kurt's face as he took a finger and lightly mussed Earl's headfur with it, "if you can't, I guess I can learn to live this way. There's worse things than being a 200-foot-tall behemoth."

Earl chuckled as he tried to smooth out his hair. "Or bigger. If the formula's doing what I think it's doing, we might not be seeing the end of your growth for some time."

"Well," Kurt plucked Earl up in his paw and stood up to his towering full height. "All the more reason to get started fixing it now."

Earl nodded and smiled, his ears now perked back up. "Okay. Then we should probably head over to…"
125322221112112.title: Something's Up... and Up... and Up...

choices: ... they're out of a key component,"
... I tripped the school's security system,"
1253222211121121.content:
Kurt balked slightly. "Wait, did I hear you right? You want me to go back to school?" he gaped.

"Well, yeah..." Earl replied slowly. "I stole most of my stuff from the chem stockroom. I mean, where else would I get half that shit?"

"I don't really know. I kinda assumed you had some super-nerd supplier or something," Kurt shrugged.

"There is a super-nerd supplier of sorts, but you have to have a teaching certificate to buy anything from it," Earl laughed. His expression got serious again. "We don't have to go if you don't want to. I understand,"

"No. Let's go. I just want to get this all done with. No use postponing the inevitable. Besides, it's Saturday afternoon. Nobody's gonna be at school, and most of the neighborhood will be in more interesting places than suburbia,"

"That's the attitude!" Earl beamed. "Er, want me to go and get a bunch of bedsheets from the house?"

Kurt raised an eyebrow. "Why would I need that,"

"Well, you know, to make a... loincloth or whatever,"

The giant raccoon hesitated. He grinned mischievously. "Nah, I'll pass, thanks. I figure being 200 feet tall at the very least entitles me to wander around in the buff. Besides, it'll give you a little eye-candy; impetus to get your tail in and out with the stuff quickly," Kurt swished his tail slightly.

Earl tried to hide a look of excitement, but failed miserably. "Suit yourself, big guy,"

Kurt blushed slightly as he left the golf course for the school and hopefully the solution to his problems. What had gotten into him? He'd beaten the shit out of this little mink not even a week ago. Now he was teasing him and walking around with him in his birthday suit. Wait, was he flirting with him? Did that count as flirting? Stop flipping out about this, dude. Focus on getting back to the school so you can stop being twenty stories tall, Kurt snapped silently at himself.

"So, the chem lab is around the back of the school," Earl called up from Kurt's palm. "I figure if you go from the big hill behind the sports fields and then hide there, you should go undetected,"

"Good plan," Kurt replied.

Altering course slightly, Kurt strode up the "tall" hill in two strides. He dropped to his knees and, curling Earl gently in a fist, began to commando-crawl towards the science hall.

"This is harder than it looks," Kurt grunted slightly.

"You're doing great. Not too far. And I'll be like ten minutes, tops," Earl encouraged.

Reaching the window of the chemistry stockroom, Kurt tapped it with a single nail, shattering the glass effortlessly.

"And you're through, tiny. I'll wait here. Don't take too long,"

"Just grab-and-go, promise. I'll mix it up at home," Earl reassured Kurt, slipping through the window.

Kurt tried to peer through the little window, but couldn't make out much more than the little mink running around like his tail was on fire. It was really great to see that he cared so much about fixing the problem. But at the same time, wasn't it taking awhile? Kurt perked up as Earl approached the window.

"Got the goods?" Kurt asked.

"Well..." Earl began hesitantly.

"That doesn't sound good," Kurt sighed.

"See," Earl sighed, "Problem is...
1253222211121121.title: Back to Where it all Began

choices: Take their chances with the Epsom salt at the drug store
Hike over the two counties and find Blake
12532222111211211.content:
Kurt pounded his fist on the ground, causing the school building to shake and some of the upstairs windows to shatter. "Dammit!" he cried out. "Well, what component is it exactly? Is it absolutely necessary?"

"I'm afraid so," the mink nodded grimly, "it's magnesium sulfate, which is what causes the mixture to turn gelatinous and controls how much of an impact it has on you."

"So, can I take the formula without it? What would happen?" Kurt asked, scratching his head.

Earl leaned on the windowsill, his chin resting on his paws. "There would be no way for us to control how much or how fast the formula would work. It could only be absorbed a little into your bloodstream and you would only get a few feet shorter."

"That doesn't sound too bad," Kurt mused. "I could just keep taking it little by little, shrinking down a few feet at a time until I'm close to where I started."

"Yeah," Earl looked up to Kurt with worried eyes, "but the more likely scenario is that your blood will absorb TOO much, and you'll start shrinking out of control, ending up a fraction of an inch tall or even smaller. You might even get down to microscopic levels, which would make it a lot harder for me to make you big again."

"Great, just great," Kurt muttered. "So my choices are either be a big and continuously growing giant, or basically disappear out of existence?" Rolling onto his back, he covered his eyes with his arm, sighing in frustration. "I sure wish you had planned this out better, Earl. Or that you hadn't planned it out at all," he added.

The mink's ears drooped, and he hopped over the window sill out of the building still carrying the other supplies he had managed to gather from the school. "Hey, listen. I'm sorry things got so out of hand. I was an idiot; you can beat the shit out of me for screwing up if you want, though I'd prefer if you waited until you got back to normal size to do so." He walked up to the right side of Kurt's face, shifted the supplies to one arm, and softly placed a paw on the raccoon's cheek.

Kurt felt the mink's touch, not reacting to it one way or another, still a little upset. "What if I can't get back, though? What if I'm like this forever?"

"Well," Earl thought as a small smile formed on his lips, "you certainly wouldn't have to worry about Eastwood High's weak side blitz in the championship game. I doubt that they'd be able to sack you, even if they sent all eleven guys at ya."

"True," Kurt said as he brought his arm back down to his side, being careful to avoid the tiny mink, "but I'm guessing the refs might not let me play quarterback if I can't fit my paws on the field." Still lying down, Kurt turned his head to look at Earl. "Wait a minute. You know football?"

"A little," Earl shrugged. "I'm more into soccer, actually. But I've picked up the ins and outs of football from watching you each week."

"Each week?" Kurt sat up, scrunching his nose. "You come to all the games?"

"Home and away," Earl nodded eagerly. "And most of the practices, too. I told ya, big guy, I idolize you!"

Kurt remained silent, not sure if he should be creeped out or flattered. Even all of the (many) girls he had gone out with didn't bother to learn anything about football while they dated him, or go to all of his games. If he hadn't spent the last 24 hours getting to know this mink better, he probably would've been freaked out by this. But something about Earl's attraction and infatuation seemed genuine, seemed admirable, seemed almost…sweet.

Stop thinking about the stupid mink, Kurt thought to himself. Quickly shaking his head to try and clear his thoughts, the giant raccoon rose to his full height of two hundred feet, picking up Earl in his hand as he did so, bringing him up to his face. "Okay, let's get focused back on what we're gonna do to get me game-eligible-size again. If the school doesn't have this magne-- magnesia--"

"Magnesium sulfate."

"Right. Whatever. If there's none here, then where can we get some?"

Earl shook his head. "There's no place I can get it pure without a certificate, unless I'm willing to go through shady internet sites and wait six to eight weeks for delivery."

"Which you're not," Kurt said as he tapped his footpaw.

"Exactly. But… magnesium sulfate is the main component in Epsom salts. Any drug store should have that. We'd have to distillate though to get it the compound in its anhydrous state, and it might not work quite the same… if at all."

Kurt took a moment to ponder this option. "Well, if it's all we've got, then--"

"There is…" Earl interrupted but then stopped, hesitating. "There is something else we could do."

"What?"

Earl sighed. "Well… I didn't exactly come up with this formula myself. I kinda 'borrowed' it from my ex."

"Your ex?" Kurt's eyes went wide in shock. Though he and the rest of the school knew the mink was gay since freshmen year, he had never seen Earl with anyone other than a couple of nerdy girls.

"Yeah. Big surprise, I know, I was actually able to get someone to date me without turning them into a giant first. Whoopee."

Kurt ignored the last part of this comment, a curiosity now burning inside him. "Who was the guy? Someone from school?"

"Sort of. He left two years ago; that's why we had to break up. He was definitely a huge closet case, though. You probably know him, actually; he played on the football team."

The raccoon's jaw dropped. A gay guy on his team? Not possible. "What? Who?"

"Blake Cadwell."

"Blake?!!!" The image of a tall, dark-furred, athletically-built wolverine instantly came to Kurt's mind. He knew Blake well; they had each started on the team as freshmen. Blake played wideout and quickly became one of Kurt's favorite targets, the two of them seeming to always be on the same page. They both earned a permeant starter spot during the second game of sophomore year, a huge upset over heavily favored St. Lamskin, where Kurt hit Blake for three touchdowns through the air and pitched to him for one more on the ground. He vividly remembered how disappointed - actually, maybe even depressed - he had been when junior year started and he found that Blake's family had abruptly moved two counties over, taking the wolverine away for good.

"There's no way Blake would've gone out with you," Kurt said, shaking his head in disbelief. "He's not a -- a fag, or gay, or whatever you want me to say. I'm sure. Positive." As Kurt thought about it, though, he could never recall Blake talking dirty about girls the way the rest of the guys on the team did, and even though he distinctly remembered Blake having a girlfriend, a short, attractive lemur whose name didn't spring to mind, now that Kurt thought about it he couldn't recall anytime when the couple shared any physical contact more intimate than hand-holding. Could Blake really be…?

Kurt snapped back from his thoughts, noticing that the mink was looking up at him, a little perturbed. "Believe what you want to believe. But we can travel two counties over and try to find Blake, then you can ask him yourself. And I know for a fact that he has all the chemicals to make this compound stashed away in his bedroom. We would always make it ourselves and then one of us (usually me) would use it, shrinking down to four or five inches tall. It was a nice enough way to have some fun while still being able to hide the other if someone came in on us. Point is, we can probably sweet talk him into giving us some magnesium sulfate."

"Okay, let me think this over for a moment." Kurt mulled over his options, trying to put his emotions and confusion aside for now and focus in on what would make the most sense and would have the greatest chance of success. It only took him a minute to make up his mind.

"Let's just take our chances with the drug store. I've seen the packages my mom uses and that epsom stuff definitely has the magnesiwhatever in it. And you should be able to get it out of the salt if you're half as smart as everyone says, right?" Kurt shrugged, starting to walk away from the school.

"Right," Earl replied, his tone somewhat snappy. "You just don't want to have to deal with facing Blake. You don't want to have to imagine the wolverine that you worked so hard with being anything but perfectly straight,"

"That's not at all what I was thinking!" Kurt protested. "Even as large as I am, it would take forever to walk two across two whole counties. And if anyone saw my gigantic, naked ass? They'd sic the army on me or something! And I don't want to end up in that situation. The drug store is much safer. It's in the middle of nowhere. I can walk nearby, drop you off, you can just go in and buy some of that shit, and we can be on our way,"

"Sure. Whatever,"

Even as he spoke, the giant kicked himself inwardly for making his worries so obvious. Maybe he was afraid of talking with Blake, whom he'd spent countless hours sweating and straining with on the football field, and finding out that he was actually gay. He didn't even want to think about him playing with a tiny little Earl, doing... well, anything with him. He was a bit disturbed and confused about this news. Was he a little jealous, too? Couldn't be. No.

"Whoa, there, big guy. You nearly passed the drug store, there," Earl called.

"Huh? Oh. Yeah. Sorry 'bout that," Kurt mumbled, his head returning to the present. He set the mink down on the concrete. "Look, I'll wait for you in that stand of trees over there across the road,"

Kurt sat down in the grove, his head spinning. So much was happening to him all at once. It was more than one guy could take, no matter how big he happened to be. Can't keep dwelling on this, Kurt told himself. You gotta get your mind off all this crap, dude.

Nothing quite cleared his mind like exercise, so Kurt rolled over and started to do push-ups. When they didn't do enough, the massive raccoon shifted onto his back, trying to get in as many crunches as possible. Hearing a branch snap nearby, Kurt sat bolt upright, looking around. He shook his head slightly, grinning a bit as he saw the little mink standing at the edge of the clearing, holding a plastic bag and trying to hide the silly grin plastered across his face.

"Let's get outta here," Kurt sighed, picking Earl up again and heading back towards the golf course.

"Well, you saved yourself a long trip, big guy. Because this stuff'll be perfect for what I need. Just great,"

"Awesome,"

"Hey, Kurt? I'm sorry if I was a little pissy earlier. I didn't mean to act like that. It just kinda... spilled out,"

"Don't bother yourself about that. Maybe you were right, a bit. I don't really know. It's just, so much has been going on that I don't know how much I can absorb at once,"

"I understand," Earl said as Kurt set him back down on the golf greens, sitting down heavily beside the mink. "Hey, I can start working on this right now, but I'm kinda nabby. I'd imagine you are, too. Want me to scrounge us up something to eat?"

"Would I ever. I'm starving,"

Kurt shrugged slightly as the mink hurried off towards his house. Minutes later, he returned, laden down with various bags and packages.

"Thank goodness my folks buy in bulk. I just grabbed a bunch of random stuff. I don't know how filling it will all be, but at least it's something,"

Kurt chowed down, opening packages with a flick of the finger and tossing their contents into his open mouth.

"Hey, Earl," Kurt said suddenly, a note of concern on his face,
125322221112112111.title: Drug Store Troubles

choices: Nothing. Nada. Zip. Zilch. Diddly-squat. Completely... well, you get the idea
Results for sure, but not exactly what they were expecting.
1253222211121121112.content:
"Are you sure?" the mink asked. Kurt noticed that Earl's face seemed a bit confused but hopeful at the same time. "I mean, this stuff from the drug store should work; we probably don't need to ask him for supplies or anything. You know, if you still think you'll be too uncomfortable picturing me and him together," he added with a wink.

"No!" The raccoon's face went flush. "I mean, I don't care about that. I just think it'd be a good idea to have a backup plan, in case something goes wrong. And besides, it'll be good to catch up with Blake, see what he's been doing for the past year and a half."

The mink wryly smiled as he popped open a soda can. "What changed your mind? Why were you so adamant about not going earlier?"

"I told you! It's too risky to travel that far in the daytime. Once it's dark, there'll be less of a chance for anyone to see me. We'll be safer." The mink tilted his head but finally nodded, seemingly satisfied with that answer for now, and Kurt breathed a sigh of relief.

As the last of the food disappeared into Kurt's mouth, he felt a rumbling coming from his gut, which still hungered for more and knew it wasn't going to be getting anything. Trying to quiet the growling, the raccoon lay down on his stomach, its roars muffled by the grass.

"So, little man, what say we get to work on that magnesium stuff. What do we need to do?"

"Well," the mink brought his paw up to his chin in thought, "I have all the equipment I need to distill and mix the formula back in my room. I can go home and make it there, then bring it back to you. Should only take me an hour or so. Tops."

"Really?" The raccoon's ears drooped slightly. "Well... okay."

"What's the matter, big guy?" Earl looked up at Kurt's massive muzzle looming over him.

"It's just..." Kurt did his best to avoid eye contact with the mink. "Just an hour alone is kinda a long time. Do you think there's any chance you could bring the stuff you need here?"

A look of surprise turned into a smile on Earl's face. "Sure. It might take me a couple of trips, but I'll go and get everything."

The mink darted off towards his house, and Kurt stayed flat on the ground, cursing himself silently. Why did he have to suddenly be so needy? He never had a problem spending large chunks of time by himself before. And it's not like if anything happened he wouldn't be able to handle it at his massive size. Maybe he just wanted to spend more time with the mink....

No, stop thinking those thoughts, Kurt thought. Earl is a nice guy, and he's been a great help in this situation, but he was just that. An acquaintance, someone who could get him back to normal, perhaps even, in time, a friend.

Closing his eyes, he saw the image of a tiny Earl crawling over Blake's naked body.

"Dammit!" Kurt sat up and slapped his head with his paw. Being so big for so long was screwing up his mind. He needed to just get home and have a good night's sleep in his own bed, at a normal size.

In bed.

With Earl.

"Motherf--!"

"Hey!" the mink's voice hissed as he appeared from the trees. "Keep your voice down. I could hear you all the way from my backyard." Kurt stared at the little mink as he skitted to a stop by his right footpaw, throwing down a heavy-looking (for Earl, anyway) backpack that landed on the ground with a loud THUD, the sound of metal clanking inside it. "I managed to get everything in one trip," he said, pulling out and snapping on a pair of safety goggles. "Shouldn't take too long to get set up."

Watching Earl with his lab equipment reminded Kurt of watching an all-star halfback weave through linemen, dodge linebackers, and hurdle over safeties, culminating in a ninety-yard-run to the end zone. A combination of wonder and disbelief gradually filled the large raccoon's mind as Earl continued to work. The mink knew exactly what he was doing, his paws nearly a blur as he quickly moved back and forth between a flask with the salts inside heated by a bunsen burner, half-a-dozen test tubes each holding their own liquids of various colors, and a largish beaker that all of the materials eventually found their way into.

After fifty minutes, he held up the main beaker to the light, swirling it around and examining the liquid sloshing inside. "Well?" Kurt asked, trying to hide the impatience in his voice.

"That's about as good as it's gonna get," Earl said, placing the beaker in the giant's outstretched paw. "There's nowhere near enough to rub into your skin like before, so just go ahead and ingest it; the effect should still be pretty much what we're going for."

Kurt brought the beaker to his face. It seemed tinier than a pea to the massive raccoon, too small for him to pickup between his thumb and forefinger without crushing it, so he just brought his palm up to his muzzle and dumped the entire thing in, formula, glass, and all.

"Great, Kurt," Earl muttered, "just great. Go ahead and eat away the rest of my equipment while you're at it."

"Hey," Kurt shrugged, "if you wanted to hang on to it you should have just hopped on and dumped it into my mouth yourself."

Earl shook his head and grinned. "Whatever. So how do you feel? Any different?"

125322221112112111212111.content:
Kurt squinted slightly, leaning in until the tip of his nose was inches from Mr. Caldwell. "How would you like to get your home remodeled for free?" he asked shortly.

The wolverine glanced back at his house, scratching his head slightly. "Eh, I like it fine the way it is right now. Why do you ask?"

"Because if you don't let Earl search your son's room, I'm going to tear your roof off and have a look myself," Kurt snapped, his brow furrowing. To be perfectly honest, Kurt wasn't entirely certain if he could even carry out his threat. He was big, alright, but tearing a roof off sounded pretty hard. The threat sounded good, though, so he let it stand.

The wolverine took a few steps back, mumbling something unintelligible to himself. "Okay, fine," he groused at length. "Just don't take too long, shrimpy! His room's up the stairs, first door on the right,"

"I--okay," Earl replied, hurrying through the door.

Kurt sat back up, waiting impatiently for Earl to return with the necessary ingredients. He drummed his fingers on his thigh as the grumpy old wolverine walked over to his steps, sitting down huffily.

"So, ah, pretty nice weather we've been having," Kurt shrugged, trying to break the frigid silence.

"Yeah. I guess. You could say that," Mr. Caldwell replied.

"You shouldn't have kicked your son out like you did," Kurt said slowly. "He's a great football player and a good guy. You should parent him, not shun him,"

"I don't want to talk about that!" the wolverine shouted. "I'm his father! I do what I want! I don't need a lecture,"

"I know. I'm just saying that being 'faggy' doesn't make or break Blake. I wish you would see that. He just wants a dad and a team, I'm sure. We're a pretty accepting group, overall. I'm sure most of the guys would understand. You should too,"

Mr. Caldwell looked like he was about to say something, but just shook his head slightly. Almost on cue, Earl came through the front door of the house.

"Any luck?" Kurt asked.

Earl sighed before saying,

1253222211121121112121111.content:
Kurt shook his head and sighed. "I knew it. I don't think we're ever gonna be able to find what we need."

"Whoa, there, big guy," Earl scolded as he started to climb up the side of Kurt's leg onto his knee, "don't give up yet. We still can go try to find Blake."

The older wolverine snorted. "Good luck with that. He's been gone for a few month now; he probably fled town."

Kurt tilted his head to the side a little. "What makes you say that? Why wouldn't he have stayed close by?"

Mr. Caldwell shrugged. "He always resented us for moving during his last few years of high school. If I were to guess, I'd say he headed back where you came from."

Earl's eyes went wide. "Really? That's ironic."

"Oh great!" Kurt slapped his head with his paw. "I had to walk for over an hour to get here, and now you're telling me that the one person who could help me is back where I started?!"

The wolverine spat on the ground. "How the hell should I know? If you want to find out, go back to your own town and look for him." He grimaced again, clearly getting more and more annoyed. Kurt fought the urge to pick him and shake him around, or put him in his mouth just to give him a scare. It was time for him and Earl to be moving on.

"Listen," he glared down at Mr. Caldwell, "we're gonna go find your son. When we do, if he wants to come back home, I'm gonna bring him back. And you'll accept him back in, or I'll… I'll stomp your house flat, without checking to see whether or not you're in it first. Got it?"

Kurt only received a grunt in response, but he took that as an affirmative, and stood up, picking Earl off of his lap and holding the mink in his paw. Turning around, he started heading back in the direction he came, hearing a door slam behind him as he did.

"Glad he's out of our lives, for now, at least," the raccoon said, looking down at Earl. "I can't believe he's such a disgusting person when Blake's such a nice guy."

Earl nodded but didn't say anything. He seemed rather quiet; unusually so, Kurt thought.

Starting to feel uncomfortable, Kurt cleared his throat. "Well," he continued, "it sucks that we have to walk another hour or two back. My paws are pretty sore."

"Listen," Earl said, seemingly ignoring Kurt's last comment, "when I said I didn't find anything back there, I wasn't telling the whole truth."

Kurt could feel his heart start beating a little faster. "What? You mean you did find something?"

"Yes," Earl nodded. "Not what we were looking for, unfortunately, but perhaps something more… interesting."

"Huh?" Confused, Kurt scratched his head a little. "What do you mean? What did you find?"

Earl reached into his pocket and pulled out a small vial. "This. It was hidden away in a safe underneath the floorboards beneath Blake's bed. Luckily, he hadn't changed the combination from back before he moved out here. It's a prototype of growth formula; the same mixture that I accidentally gave you yesterday."

"Really?" At first, Kurt couldn't help but feel disappointed, but after a few moments, he sensed himself becoming excited at the thought of using it and growing again. Maybe he had gotten used to this giant thing after all.

"After I found out he was moving," Earl continued, "we promised that we would try it out together once we were able to meet up again. I think though, that under the circumstances, he wouldn't mind if…"

12532222111211211121211111.content:
"Oh, okay that'll work," Kurt said, starting to feel a bit excited. 

"You sure you're okay with this?" Earl asked. 

"Yeah, it's all good," Kurt smiled. "Just pour it on in,"

Kurt lifted the mink over his open mouth and waited patiently as Earl uncapped the vial and emptied it's contents into the giant's maw. Just as soon as Kurt had set Earl down between his feet, a crippling wave of nausea passed through his body. He squeezed his eyes shut and gritted his teeth, just wanting the pain to be over. 

As soon as it had subsided, Kurt opened his eyes and gasped slightly. He had more than doubled in size, towering at around 450 feet in height. 

Squatting down and offering the now much smaller Earl a palm, Kurt laughed slightly at the ridiculousness of the whole situation. 

"We'd better hurry," Earl said as Kurt began to walk off again. "It gets light in a few hours,"

"Oh, I don't think I mind anyone seeing me naked anymore," Kurt replied. "I've worked so hard toning every muscle in my body just right, I deserve to show it off,"

"That's not my worry, though you are very sexy," Earl blushed. "I think you'll cause a panic if you're in town when the sun comes up. A giant raccoon? There'll be public hysteria! We need to get you somewhere relatively hidden as soon as we find Blake,"

"You've got a point," Kurt sighed. He hesitated before caressing Earl's body with his lips. 

"Hey! You just about swallowed me there," Earl complained. 

"I was just trying to kiss you, sorry..." Kurt mumbled. 

"Well, try to be more careful with your intimacy in the future,"

"Duly noted. Alright, if I were a homeless wolverine, where would I go?"

"I dunno. A friend's house?"

"But he never stopped by my place..."

"Kurt, think for a second. Blake probably wouldn't visit your place trying to get a bed because he think you would just laugh in his face and slam the door. He would be just another faggot,"

"That's not the truth!" Kurt shouted, stomping on a tree and causing it to crumple like a dry leaf. 

"Really?"

Kurt's ears drooped slightly. Maybe Earl was right. Blake had been one of his closest friends before he'd left. But would that have changed if he'd come to him seeking refuge? He wished it weren't true, but Earl probably had his likely response about summed up. Kurt felt horrible. Things are different now, Kurt thought to himself. Blake needs help. Now. 

"Why didn't he go to your house?"

"I honestly couldn't tell you. My parents are pretty open about most stuff. I think they would've understood. Maybe Blake is somewhere else,"

"But where?  I can't just go walking through the streets--"

"Wait a minute!" Earl interrupted. "The freight yard! There's plenty of empty shipping containers by the railroad tracks. Blake could have hunkered down there,"

"You're a genius," Kurt said. He picked up his pace and altered his course slightly. 

Soon enough, the pair arrived in the deserted freight yards. They split up, Earl running from boxcar to boxcar and Kurt picking them up one by one to search their contents. 

"Blake!" Kurt heard Earl cry and dashed over to the mink, lying down on his stomach to get a better look. 

The mink and the wolverine were embracing each other. Their tails coiled around one another as they kissed. Kurt couldn't help but feel a twinge of jealousy as he watched in silence. 

"Oh, gods, Earl. I'm so scared," Blake gasped between kisses. 

"I'm here now. It's ok. And I brought a friend,"

Blake's jaw dropped as he noticed the giant for the first time. 

"KURT? Holy fuck it's you!"

"Hey," Kurt grinned sheepishly. "Hope you don't mind if I sorta borrowed some of your growth stuff,"

"Just so long as you didn't borrow my boyfriend too," Blake laughed. Kurt and Earl exchanged uncomfortable looks. "But why on earth are you so huge?"

"Long story," Kurt and Earl said in unison. "Can you help us fix it?"

"Sure. Wait..." Blake said, catching one of Kurt's sidelong glances at Earl. "There's something you two aren't telling me,"

"Er, oh gods... we had sex, Blake. I'm really sorry," Earl mumbled after several moments of silence. "I'm really sorry. It just sorta happened,"

"What the FUCK, Earl?" Blake shouted. "We don't see each other for a few months and you go banging the first guy you see? I thought what we had meant something. I thought I meant something," 

"It wasn't that. It was just a silly dare. I'm not trying to steal--" Kurt realized his mistake too late. Earl had his face buried in his paws and Blake looked livid. 

"A DARE?" Blake bellowed. "That's what it takes, Earl? A dare? You fucked some godsdamn giant-ass raccoon who wanted to pretend he was gay or something--"

"That was not pretend!" Kurt snapped. "I wanted it. I dunno.  Maybe I'm bi or maybe he just attracts me or I don't know. None of this shit is written in stone,"

"And so the best way to explore would naturally be to use MY boyfriend as a sex-toy,"

"We were trying to find you. To help you. And to help me,"

"And don't even get me started on you helping you," Blake shouted. "Its always been about you. Kurt the football star. Kurt this, Kurt that. Well now all you're good for is the team bus so maybe that'll teach you,"

"Er, boys?" Earl cut in for the first time. "It would appear we've got more pressing issues at the moment..."

Kurt looked around to see...

125322221112112111212111111.content:
“The police?!” Kurt whispered, kneeling to the ground and unsuccessfully trying to conceal himself. “Why would they come down here at this time of night?”

“Well, it’s not like we’ve been very quiet since we’ve been down here,” Earl commented. “You know, Kurt, your voice kinda carries a ways...”

“Great. Thanks a lot, asshole,” Blake snarled, throwing his arms in the air in disgust. “Now they’re gonna catch us and arrest us. They'll probably send me back to the wonderland that is my parents' house. And YOU," he paused for emphasis as he pointed a finger at the giant raccoon, "they'll send YOU off to some strange lab to be examined and experimented on for the rest of your life.”

Frowning, Kurt shook his head. “Not if I have anything to do with it! Hang on, guys.”

"Hang on?" Earl asked. "What do you-- OOF!" He stopped talking as his muzzle was covered by one of Kurt's index fingers. The raccoon reached out and grabbed both Earl and Blake with one paw, lifting them up into the air, and then took off running.

"OW! What the fuck?!" Blake cried out. "Let me go!! Put me down!!"

Kurt momentarily ignored the screaming from his wolverine passenger as he quickly stepped over the freight cars and tried to make his way out of the train-yard, trying to be as silent as possible. Unfortunately, he accidentally hit his paw against a car, knocking it over on its side, and the loud clanging sound attracted the attention of every single one of the incoming policemen.

One of them, near a parked cruiser, turned on a spotlight that was mounted to the top of the car and shone it directly at Kurt's face, causing the raccoon to wince and shield his eyes with his free paw.

"Stop!" Kurt heard the gruff, firm voice of one of the police officers coming through some sort of megaphone, but he couldn't make out exactly who or where it was coming from. "Put down the two civilians and slowly kneel to the ground, paws in the air."

"Great," Earl sighed, having managed to work his muzzle free. "Just great." He shook his head and closed his eyes.

"Whoa, whoa," Kurt called out to the policemen, turning his head around quickly as he did, his vision still obscured by the bright light in his eyes. "I'm not trying to hurt anybody. These are my friends, I promise! This is all just a huge accident."

But the officer wasn't going to hear any of it. "I'll repeat: Release the two hostages and get down to the ground. This is your last warning!"

"But wait--" Kurt tried to protest.

"Men, ready your weapons!" Kurt heard several dozen loud clicking sounds coming from near his feet. "Fire on three!"

"Hey, Earl," Kurt looked down to the mink, "I can't see very well right now. How many policemen are there?"

"Um," Earl quickly counted. "Probably about seventy or eighty."

"One!" The officer's voice boomed throughout the train-yard, starting his countdown.

"And are they all pointing their guns at me?"

"You got it."

"Great." Kurt grimaced, imagining the feeling of several hundred bullets hitting his pelt all at once. "What should I do?"

"Uhhhh…." Earl's voice trailed off as he tried to rack his brain for ideas.

"Two!"

"I've got an idea," Blake screamed up towards Kurt. "How about you either put us down like he said and surrender, or get us the fuck out of here?"

1253222211121121112121111111.content:
"Alright! Okayokayokay I surrender," Kurt said hastily, setting the pair down and getting down on all fours, trying to make himself appear less threatening. "I just don't want anyone getting hurt,"

While he'd briefly toyed with the idea of hightailing it out of there, Kurt didn't want to risk the repercussions. His massive stature likely wasn't that hard of a target to hit and he really didn't want to find out how it felt to be hit with sixty or seventy bullets at one time.

The cops swarmed up towards him. Several took Blake and Earl off to one side, questioning them loudly.

"No, we don't know him," Blake snapped at the police officer. "I was staying over at Earl's house and this big freak... kidnapped us! We just want to get home,"

"That's not true!" Kurt shouted, but a quick gesture with the gun of a policeman shut him up. He cast a look at Earl, trying to get the mink to say something to rectify the wolverine's story. It was no good. Earl's ears were drooped and he was sitting on the curb looking dejected.

"Alright. You two come with Officer Baker. He'll get you home so you can have a little chat with the parents," the lead policeman instructed Earl and Blake. The wolverine cast Kurt a final withering glance before turning to follow Earl and the officer back into a car.

Kurt found himself alone surrounded by police officers. None of them were any larger than a knuckle on his finger, but the raccoon couldn't help but feel creeping dread begin to set in. Blake was right. He was a giant freak, doomed to a life of experimentation in some sunless cell, isolated from everything else.

"Here's how we're going to do this," the officer instructed curtly. "You will follow the police vehicles at a distance of 100 feet. Remain on all fours. Should you try anything... well, just don't. A detail of the National Guard is arriving and they are prepared to use deadly force if necessary,"

Kurt nodded sullenly and waited for all of the cops to get back in their cars. As the bizarre caravan set off, Kurt saw that the cop hadn't been bluffing. Armed individuals surrounded him as he crawled down the street after the police escort. For perhaps the first time since his massive growth spurt, Kurt felt embarrassed about his nudity. He was thankful for his large bushy tail. At least it protected his modesty a bit.

This must look odd to anyone who looks out their window at this hour, Kurt snorted slightly. A bajillion cops, little army dudes, and a giant, naked quarterback! Best parade ever.

Unfortunately, the end of the "parade" didn't seem to be all that positive for Kurt. After a short interval of time, he saw that the destination in mind was...

“Three!”

Kurt took off like a bullet, though at his size, perhaps ‘like a rocket’ would be a better descriptor. Police officers fired hurriedly, following their fleeing target and trying to avoid getting crushed underpaw.

Kurt smiled wanly. "Thanks, buddy. But, Blake, I'll let you go,"

The wolverine remained silent for a moment. Eventually, he shook his head. "No, I'll stay. I guess I was kinda unfair to you earlier. I'll help you out,"

"That's great! Thank you,"

"Alright. We'll start working on this tomorrow. But there's no point in doing anything more tonight. I'm beat," Earl said.

Kurt set the pair down beside him. They went a short distance away, taking shelter under the canopy of a large tree. Kurt laid down on his side, willing sleep to come. As he drifted off, he saw a single light penetrating the darkness of the forest. Curious, he sat up to investigate. It was...
1253222211121121112121111112.title: Kurt's Great Escape

choices: "You have two seconds to get off my property before I start shooting."
12532222111211211121211111121.content:
A cabin? Kurt thought to himself. Why hadn't he seen that earlier? Did the light just turn on, or had it been there this whole time, and he had just been too distracted (or too exhausted) to notice it? Whatever the case, Kurt thought, it warranted action. After all, if he was close enough to see it, then whoever was inside was close enough to see him.

Kurt mulled his options for a moment. He could pick up Earl and Blake, who had fallen asleep on the ground in front of him, and take them further into the woods. But that wouldn't necessarily guarantee safety, as by doing so, he could easily attract the attention of the person at the cabin (or anyone else, for that matter), and who was to say that he'd be able to find an isolated enough spot so that no one would be able to find him?

Another option was to just remain here and hope he wouldn't be spotted. That would be the path of least resistance, sure, but it could also spell trouble if whoever was in the cabin DID end up seeing him and decided to call the cops. Plus, at this point, Kurt was too curious to not find out just who would be living so far out in the woods like this.

No, Kurt finally decided, his best option was to go ahead and check out the cabin, seeing if the person there was going to be a problem and, if so, deal with it. He repeated those words again in his mind. Deal with it? What exactly did that mean? The raccoon didn't want to kill anybody, that was for damn sure, but the other options he had were limited. He'd just have to figure things out as they went, he guessed.

Making sure not to disturb the sleeping Blake and Earl, Kurt slowly got to his hands and knees and began crawling towards the cabin.

"Dammit," he yelped as he felt the pinch of the rough pine needles scraping against his back, many of them getting stuck in his fur. Moving around as a giant was a difficult enough task; more than once he had to squeeze through two particularly close trees that didn't budge easily. Finally, though, he made it within a hundred feet of the cabin, able to see it clearly and try to figure out what was going on.

It seemed fairly small, as cabins went (not that Kurt had any experience as a realtor or anything to base that judgement on). "Probably only one room inside," he mused. "Must be pretty old." He tried to think back to history class, vaguely remembering that the first settlers had come to this area over two centuries ago; this building could very well be from then. Of course, it could also have been constructed just this past summer, built by a vacation homes company to give campers that "rustic, outdoors feel". Whatever the case, the lack of any visible power or telephone lines meant whoever was inside probably woulnd't be able to call the cops on him if they did end up freaking out (unless they had a cell phone, he realized, but he figured the service out here was probably not so good).

As Kurt examined the building more closely, the light from the window suddenly moved, and he heard the sound of the front door creaking open. Panicked, he tried to back away, but smacked right into a large tree. The force of his impact caused the tree to teeter, and then come crashing down, hitting several other trees and making a loud bang.

"So much for being subtle," he thought to himself. Looking down at the door, he saw a silhouetted figure holding a lantern looking up at him. At this angle, Kurt realized the person wasn't even as big as his foot paw. He squinted his eyes, trying to give his best shot at figuring out who was there, but it was too dark for him to even make out the gender or species, much less any details.

"Um," the enormous raccoon started, grinning sheepishly. "Hi. Sorry if I woke you up."

Taking a long, deep breath, the figure took a moment before they replied,

“Well... yeah, you’re probably right,” Kurt conceded. “But this is really important to me. Besides being normal again, I guess. Look, I’ve got an idea. There’s a big forested hill behind the stadium at my school. I’ll hide out there and keep quiet,”

Owyn hesitated again. He scratched his head and fidgeted as Kurt nervously awaited an answer. “You know what? Fine. Go on ahead,” he finally said.

Kurt beamed for the first time in awhile. “Thank you. It really means a lot. And I’ll be careful, I promise,”

“Good, because I’m really kinda busy at the moment. I won’t be able to go with you,” Owyn replied. “The game’s tonight, right? Well, you might want to head over there now. We’re about five miles or so away from your school. Just head due east until you get there. Can’t miss it. Oh, and shut up while you’re there. Your voice kinda carries,”

“Got it,” Kurt grinned as a massive sliding door was opened on the far side of the room. He started to crawl towards the exit.

“Don’t make me regret this!” Owyn called after the giant. “I’m giving you a huge amount of freedom here!”

“Everything about me is huge,” Kurt chuckled as he stood up outside of the building he’d been housed in. “I’ll be back afterward,”

It took the giant quarterback about 10 minutes to reach the stadium. Thankful that the early darkness of the late fall evening covered him, he laid down on the far side of the hill, propping his chin in his hands, just in time for the opening kick-off.

Kurt watched the game unfold with baited breath. It was a truly intense game with his team’s district rivals, and it was quite surreal for the giant watching the game being played by tiny action figures. Every play unfolded beautifully and every down was fought for tooth and nail.

By the final moments of the fourth quarter, it was still a tied game. The stands were buzzing with nervous energy as the home team prepared to make a final push. The snap went off and the (substitute) quarterback belted the ball down the field. The ball was caught perfectly and the wide receiver barreled down the final yards to the end zone. They’d done it. They’d won.

“YESSSSS!” Kurt bellowed, leaping to his feet and pumping his fist, unable to control his happiness.

The entire stadium fell deathly silent as Kurt realized his mistake. Everyone was staring at the huge giant who had just appeared over the hill, faces blank with shock and surprise. Almost instantaneously, everyone was in a panic, pushing and running for the nearest exits. The stands were nearly cleared in a matter of moments.

“Oh no,” Kurt groaned. “That’s not what...”

His ears perked up as he heard sirens in the distance. His blood running cold, Kurt began to run. He had no idea where he was going or how to get there, but he knew he had to get away, and as quickly as possible. Kurt stumbled down the hill towards the stadium.

Kurt nearly jumped up in celebration, but remembered the low ceiling at the last minute. “Great!” he exclaimed. “What do we need to do?”

“So I noticed,” Kurt muttered. “But, if all that energy led to my growth, how can we reverse that?”

“That’s the thing,” Owyn replied. “We can’t.”

“What?!” Kurt’s brow furrowed as he started to ball his hands into fists. “I thought you said you figured it out!”

“I did!” The other three looked at him questioningly as he continued. “Actually, I didn't exactly figure out how to get rid of the excess energy. Once the reaction in the serum has occurred, it's like Pandora’s Box, it can't be reversed and consolidated again. But, I realized that if we were able to redirect that energy somewhere else, then your cells would quickly rebalance themselves back to how they were, and you would (hopefully) shrink back to normal.”

“Wait,” Earl interjected, the gears in his head spinning rapidly, “what are you saying?”

“I’m saying,” Owyn replied as he took a deep breath, "that our best chance for success is to try and transfer all that energy to...

Immediately upon grabbing the cable, Kurt felt a tingling sensation all over his body. It wasn't entirely unpleasant, but it definitely was strange, and Kieran let out a small, involuntary yelp of surprise, which caused him to quickly blush.

"Are you okay, Kurt?" Owyn asked, looking up at the giant with concern.

"Uh, I think so." Kurt noticed that his voice had a slight abnormal vibration to it, as if he was being shaken while talking, and his vision started to blur a little. "This definitely feels weird though. Do I look okay? Am I getting any smaller?"

"Maybe," Earl answered. "It's hard to tell. Your fur is all standing on its end, so that makes you look kinda bigger just cause of that."

"Great," Kurt moaned, "Just what I needed."

"You're definitely getting smaller, though!" Blake shouted. "You're already about fifty feet shorter."

Indeed, Kurt noticed that his surroundings looked a little bigger in comparison. His heart started beating faster in excitement (well, more likely due to the voltage flowing through it), and he began to smile. "Finally! Something I do to try to fix this works!"

He continued shrinking for about a minute. Once he got to a little over two hundred feet, however, the lights dotting the perimeter of the power station began to flicker, getting brighter and then dimmer in rapid succession. What was worse, though, was the fact that the tingling feeling was quickly growing increasingly painful.

"What's-- what's happening?"

"Uh, I don't know!" Owyn started to panic, running over to the boxes and hastily examining them. "I think their might be an overload on these transformers. Hang on, I'll flip the safety shut-off!" He ran around in a panic, as Blake and Earl rushed over to try and help.

Kurt's body began to convulse. He tried to just drop the cables, but the muscles in his hands and arms seemed to be paralyzed; he didn't seem to have control over any part of his body at the moment. So this is it, he thought to himself, I'm about to die while still a giant. I hope they can find a place with enough room to dispose of my body in a somewhat respectful fashion."

"Found it!" he heard Owyn cry out. "Hang on!" Kurt heard the loud clunking sound of a switch being moved, and the lights immediately went out, cloaking them in darkness. But, thankfully, the electricity quickly ceased flowing through his body, and the pain quickly reverted to the tingling feeling, which soon faded away as he quickly fell down to the ground with a loud thud.

The badger, mink, and wolverine quickly ran up to Kurt's feet, looking up at him with hope, worry, and fear. Shaking his head and opening his eyes again, he tried to give a weak smile. "Let's not try that again anytime soon."

"Kurt!" Relief washed over Earl's face as he saw the raccoon was still alive and in relatively good health. "Thank gods you're okay."

"Hey," Kurt said as he sat up, beginning to regain his strength, "It'll take more than one power station's worth of electricity to sideline this raccoon."

"Well," Owyn said, "you've definitely lost some of the height you had, but you're still around two hundred feet tall or so. If you're up for it, there's a power station a little closer to town that we could head to and try this again."

Kurt shook his head. "Not tonight. Maybe in the morning. C'mon, let's head back to your lab."

He picked the three up in his paw again, which was a little less roomy than before but still plenty big to carry them. The walk back to Owyn's took a little bit longer than before, but the cool fall air was pleasing enough, especially against his frazzled fur.

But something wasn't right. As Kurt got closer to Owyn's, he began to realize what was happening.

"What. The. Fuck," Kurt said slowly. He had certainly changed, though not as he had anticipated. The gigantic raccoon now towered at more than twice his earlier stature, easily surpassing 450 feet in height. A snarl erupted from Kurt's lips as he snatched Earl off the ground, bringing him up to his enraged face. "Fuck it, Earl! Can't you manage to do anything without fucking something up!"

"I oughta crush you," Kurt snarled.

He couldn't take looking at the mink anymore. Dropping him back to the ground, Kurt stood up to his full height and stormed off. Trees smashed and pavement cracked under the massive quarterback's heavy footfalls as he strode away from Earl and the golf course. He had no destination in mind, but his feet led him perhaps instinctively back to the football field.

Sitting down heavily on top of the bleachers, Kurt buried his face in his hands. He wanted to cry, but he couldn't manage it. He was going to be a giant forever. There was no way around it. No more football, no more driving around with his friends, no more friends, period. He would have to hide somewhere. The mountains would do. He could hide out, subsisting on the local vegetation and wildlife. Perhaps he could steal from campers and hikers on occasion. Or, he could throw subtlety to the wind and enslave a town, forcing its inhabitants to carry out his every whim. Maybe that would be fun.

"Go ahead. Do it," came a faint voice.

Kurt looked down to see Earl standing by his hip. "What do you mean, 'do it'?" he asked.

"Kill me. Crush me, eat me, I don't care. I don't deserve to live. I'm a failure," Earl mumbled.

Kurt picked Earl up, regarding him closely. The mink's shoulders were slumped, his ears drooping, and his cheeks were damp with tears. He looked like he was trying to be determined, but fear and sadness kept seeping through. Maybe I should. The little fucker put me in this horrible situation, Kurt thought. Part of him wanted to drop the mink into his mouth and swallow him whole, ensuring a slow and excruciating death. But the pit of anger seemed to be gone, for some reason. "Earl, little guy, I can't do that," Kurt finally said.

"Kill me! Kill me!" Earl sobbed. "I'm a miserable fuck-up. I can't even make you normal again. This is all my--"
